title: Quiz 6: Literature & Methodology
description: Assess your ability to identify literature sources and select appropriate research methodologies.

questions.question: Which of the following is considered a PRIMARY source of literature?

options.text: A thesis or dissertation by the original researcher
A textbook chapter summarizing a theory
A review article in a journal

questions.explanation: Primary sources are original works by the person who created the idea or conducted the study (e.g., theses, empirical reports).

questions.question: A ___BLANK___ source involves summaries or quoted content from a primary source and is usually written by someone who was not a direct observer.
questions.explanation: Secondary sources interpret or summarize primary sources (e.g., textbooks, review articles).

questions.question: What are the main purposes of a literature review? (Select all that apply)

options.text: To determine what has already been done
To identify useful strategies and instruments
To copy exact paragraphs to fill space

questions.explanation: Literature review serves to position the new study within existing knowledge, not to copy content.

questions.question: Match the information source to its description:

pairs.right: Policy papers, annual reports, ministry reports

questions.explanation: Journals=Refereed; Theses=Student research; Gov Docs=Official reports; MEDLINE=Database.

questions.question: When selecting a research design, the availability of resources (budget) is NOT a factor to consider.
questions.explanation: False. Resource availability (money, time, skills) is a critical factor in selecting a feasible design.
questions.hint: Can you do a study with no money?

questions.question: A researcher wants to compare the prevalence of measles in two different districts. Which design is most appropriate?
questions.explanation: Comparative descriptive design allows for comparing variables (measles prevalence) between two or more groups (districts).

questions.question: What type of descriptive design provides information on the prevalence, incidence, and correlates of disease in a population?
questions.explanation: Epidemiologic research focuses on disease distribution and determinants in populations.

questions.question: Which design is best suited for generating hypotheses about a relatively unknown field of inquiry?
questions.explanation: Exploratory designs are used to explore new problems and generate initial ideas or hypotheses.

questions.question: Arrange the steps of the Literature Review process logically:
questions.explanation: Find library -> Identify sources -> Locate documents -> Analyze content.

questions.question: A study design that starts in the present and follows subjects into the future is called:
questions.explanation: Prospective studies look forward in time (future).
